channel.title: Wireless encryption etc
channel.description:
I haven't been using it for a few months now, because I'd rather use the 'New stations are not allowed'; feature for many reasons. Just annoys me trying to connect with different devices and not being let in because of the wrong key, when I can simply allow it from my PC.
Does this encryption encrypt my transfers or does it just encrypt access to the network. Nobody can get on it, I'm just wondering if somebody could intercept packets and get my paypal password...

item.title: Wireless encryption etc
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote="["]link=topic=331476.msg2588014#msg2588014 date=1229622008]
Alright then. I don’t normally use my linux boot so is there a way to do it in windows easily? With my shitty free bt router?

I suppose I could just use linux if I’m doing something important (boots in seconds :P) so can I have your script? :D[/quote]

In windows you can use Putty to set up the socks5 proxy through an ssh server. Google for a tutorial.

Here is my script, with personal details removed (if you wonder why I keep trying, it’s because when you connect wirelessly you obviously have to set up the connection to the router before you can ssh into a server):

#!/bin/sh
killall ssh;
killall ssh;
echo "starting";
while true; do
	# make sure you use an IP instead of a domain if you don't want to do a DNS lookup in the open
        # also, if you run this automatically you have to set up ssh to not require a password, google that as well
	ssh -fND localhost:1080 user@ip > /dev/null 2> /dev/null;
	if [ -n "$(netstat -na | grep "LISTEN" | grep ":1080")" ]
	then
		break;
	fi
	echo "failed";
	sleep 5;
done
echo "success";

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless encryption etc
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:6, topic:251185”]I am so far away from anywhere that no one will hack me.

My room gets “Very Poor” reception from my WiFi router which is just upstairs and 15 metres away.[/quote]

My sister connects to the router, and shes right next door, about 10 feet? if you walk from the router to inside her room, and she gets poor reception. There is a wall exactly where her computer is(On the other side), a door, another door, and she connects the adapter to the front of the computer so the legs block the signal.(excluding the digital devices from here to her room). And about across the street, 20 meters away, a friend of mines get perfect reception. So he objects in the way play a part too.

If the poor connection to your other room upstairs is a problem, i forget the name of the router, but it sends the signal everywhere(multi directional?), instead of 1 way.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless encryption etc
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Client-side amplifiers/antennas, while not perfect, DO actually help with most wlan setups, contrary to popular belief. If you can’t get reception from the road, don’t assume nobody can.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:6, topic:251185”]I am so far away from anywhere that no one will hack me.

My room gets “Very Poor” reception from my WiFi router which is just upstairs and 15 metres away.[/quote]

Actually, the room next to me gets average reception and it’s very low anywhere downstairs so I’m pretty much safe from random people… Can’t believe I never thought about that.

item.title: Wireless encryption etc
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

You should use WPA2, WEP is just to avoid noobs to connect your network.
That will encrypy the package.

You need SSL or other encryption to be completely secure and of course, be virus (And other things like that) free.

If you have a keylogger its helps little that your network is completely secure with encryptions.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless encryption etc
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Secure sites that use SSL should be secure even over an unsecured network. Wireless encryption actually restricts access and encrypts the data you send, problem is most encryption mechanisms are very easily cracked. Someone with the right card and one of many sniffing/cracking programs that abound for free on the internet can have access to your network within a few minutes.

If you really want the packets you send flying through the air to be truly safe, do what I do. Route all of your traffic through SSH to your router (assuming your router has an ssh daemon running, if not any server that you can log into with ssh will work). This is much easier than you would think, with the proper command ssh can start up a socks5 proxy on your local machine. Set your browser to use that as your proxy, and your traffic is automatically encrypted with the uncrackable (unless you are the NSA) SSL encryption and perfectly safe in between your computer and wherever you had ssh connect to.

I have a script written for linux that runs every time I log in to automatically set up this connection for you that I can post later when I’m on my laptop if anyone is interested.

Meanwhile, refer here for more info:
http://wiki.freaks-unidos.net/weblogs/azul/firefox-ssh-tunnel

Read full topic
